article.description: Lionel Chalmers, playing just his second game since returning from a broken foot, scored 17 points to lead Xavier (No. 19 ESPN/USA Today, No. 20 AP) to an 80-68 victory over George Washington on Tuesday night.
article.headline: Chalmers' broken foot a memory as he scores 17
article.linkText: Chalmers' foot just fine in Xavier's win vs. George Washington
article.story: WASHINGTON (AP) --Lionel Chalmers simply ignored his teammates. In just his second game since returning from a broken foot, Chalmers scored 17 points, including a timely 3-pointer late in the second half, to lead Xavier (No. 19 ESPN/USA Today, No. 20 AP) to an 80-68 victory over George Washington on Tuesday night. Xavier (16-4, 7-1 Atlantic 10) led 62-59 with five minutes to play when the rusty Chalmers was left open on the wing in front of the Xavier bench. "The entire team was like, 'Lionel, don't shoot it!''' Xavier forward David West said. "Then he hit it. It was during that stretch where were up three and couldn't get a basket.'' Chalmers, who played 20 minutes as a reserve, hit three of Xavier's seven 3-pointers and scored 10 points in the second half as the Musketeers won their seventh straight. "It feels good to be out there and on the court,'' said Chalmers, who broke his foot against Creighton on Dec. 31, and missed seven games after undergoing surgery. "When I need to step up I'm going to do that.'' The Musketeers got plenty of support for West, who finished with 13 points and 13 rebounds for his eight straight double-double. West's seventh rebound game of the game made him the conference's all-time leading rebounder as he passed former George Washington player Mike Brown, who finished his career with 1,166 rebounds. "I didn't know about it. It was something my manager told me this morning,'' West said. "It wasn't something I was chasing, but it was a great accomplishment.'' Chris Monroe had 17 points for the Colonials (8-11, 2-6), who lost for the seventh time in nine games. The Colonials led 54-53 with 8:52 left after two free throws by T.J. Thompson. Xavier then went on a 9-0 run that was capped by two free throws by West. "We wanted their guards to beat us with perimeter shooting,'' George Washington coach Karl Hobbs said. "It's just the GW way that Chalmers had his warmup game against Richmond to get him ready and, of course, he came in here full steam ready to go.'' The Colonials got within 62-59, but were outscored 18-9 over the final 5:12. Freshman Dedrick Finn, who started at point guard while Chalmers was injured, hit two straight 3-pointers to start the second half and kick off a 14-4 run that pushed the lead to 11 points with 16:38 to play. George Washington took an 8-6 lead, only to have Xavier go on a 12-2 run over the next three minutes. The Musketeers led 31-30 at halftime. West's record rebound came with 2:55 to play in the first half when he partially deflected a short jumper by Thompson and collected the rebound.
